Taking the last argument first, I observe that one trait in St. James’s description, αὐτοὶ ἕλκουσιν ὑμᾶς εἰς κριτήρια, 13 not to be found in Hermas, and it seems very improbable that actual members of the Church, though from cowardice (Sim. ix. 21. 3> they might apostatize and give information against their brethren, would themselves take the lead in dragging them before the magistrate. I observe also that there is nothing in our epistle to suggest that the court was Roman rather than J ewish 5 nor again that the rich persecutors were Christians. As Dr. Plummer has pointed out, the Holy Name was not called over them, but (ἐφ’ ὑμᾶς) over those whom they arrested. The whole passage (ii. 2-7) is directed against the respect of persons shown in favouring the rich at the expense of the poor ; this is illustrated by the supposi- tion of two strangers visit-ing the synagogue, of whom nothing is known, except that one is well dressed, the other in shabby clothes St. J ames says their hearts should have been drawn rather to the poor than to the rich, because the poor made up the bulk of the Christian community, while the rich were their persecutors. If ‘we want a parallel to the ‘ dragging before the tribunals,' we find one ready to our hand in Acts viii. 3, where Saul, σύρων ἄνδρας καὶ «γυναῖκας, committed them to prison.
